_comment: Created by EFisher on 12/10/2015 14:29:22 using v2.7
title: Are there differences between staff groups in reporting working extra hours?
analysis_commentary:
The extent to which different staff groups report working extra hours varies quite dramatically between the groups.

Of the staff groups we've investigated three clinical staff groups (medical/dental, registered nurses and health visitors) report working extra hours more than the national average (by approximately 10% more). However, this is not as great a difference when looking at general managers; across the years 20% more staff in this group report working extra hours when compared to national results.

There was also variation in staff reporting working extra hours based on staff characteristics. More male staff reported working extra hours than females, this ranged between 4% and 7% greater than what is reported nationally in each year (data not shown). Also there is a consistent difference in how many staff report working extra hours based on staff age. Less 16 to 30 year olds (on average across all years 3% less ) and more 41 to 50 year olds (on average across all years 3.5% more ) report working extra hours compared to looking at the number of staff reporting nationally (data not shown).
